image.altText: Without A Fight runs ahead of other horses

items.synopsis: Without A Fight wins the Melbourne Cup, becoming the first horse in 22 years to complete the Melbourne-Caulfield Cup double. Follow live.

title.children: Without A Fight wins Melbourne Cup with Mark Zahra winning consecutive Cups

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: To complete the top four, Ashrun — who was in his fourth run back after missing 1,000 days through injury — produced an amazing run to finish just out of the placings. Right You Are came slowly over the line in last place, and has being checked by vets and is believed to be heat-stressed. Read the full details of the Melbourne Cup finishing order.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The finishing order of the Melbourne Cup

featuredLink.title: The complete Melbourne Cup finishing order from first to last

children.content: To complete the top four, Ashrun — who was in his fourth run back after missing 1,000 days through injury — produced an amazing run to finish just out of the placings.
Right You Are came slowly over the line in last place, and has being checked by vets and is believed to be heat-stressed.
Read the full details of the Melbourne Cup finishing order.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Without A Fight does the Caulfield Cup - Melbourne Cup double, ridden by Mark Zahra. Second was Soulcombe, and third was Sheraz. The win gives Anthony and Sam Freedman their first Cup win.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Without A Fight wins the Melbourne Cup!

children.content: Without A Fight does the Caulfield Cup - Melbourne Cup double, ridden by Mark Zahra.
Second was Soulcombe, and third was Sheraz.
The win gives Anthony and Sam Freedman their first Cup win.

items.synopsis: The RBA has lifted the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points in November, taking the rate to 4.35 per cent, while the Australian share market is trading lower. Follow live.

title.children: RBA lifts interest rates to 12-year high of 4.35pc, WeWork files for bankruptcy in US, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're seeing a lot of comments coming through telling us that you're already doing it tough at the moment and are worried about what the future holds for you now the RBA has lifted rates again. If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access. National Debt Helpline : 1800 007 007 Mob Strong Debt Help : 1800 808 488 ASIC's Moneysmart website Australian Financial Complaints Authority Find a financial counsellor Lifeline : 13 11 14 Beyond Blue : 1300 224 636 (This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another tidbit from Ms Bullock's post-meeting statement is that the RBA has revised how it sees the unemployment rate. She notes that high inflation is having an impact on people's income and there is weak growth in household consumption, which will impact employment data. "Given that the economy is forecast to grow below trend, employment is expected to grow slower than the labour force and the unemployment rate is expected to rise gradually to around 4.25% ," she noted. "This is a more moderate increase than previously forecast." Ms Bullock also noted that, to date, "medium-term inflation expectations have been consistent with the inflation target" and that it's important "that this remains the case".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA expects unemployment rate to 'rise gradually' to 'moderate' 4.25pc

children.content: Another tidbit from Ms Bullock's post-meeting statement is that the RBA has revised how it sees the unemployment rate.
She notes that high inflation is having an impact on people's income and there is weak growth in household consumption, which will impact employment data.
"Given that the economy is forecast to grow below trend,
employment is expected to grow slower than the labour force
and
the unemployment rate is expected to rise gradually to around 4.25%
," she noted.
"This is
a more moderate increase
than previously forecast."
Ms Bullock also noted that, to date, "medium-term inflation expectations have been consistent with the inflation target" and that it's important "that this remains the case".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Most economists had expected the RBA would lift rates by 0.25 percentage points at today's meeting — but the response to the decision has been varied. Here's how some have reacted to the development. Stephen Smith, Deloitte Access Economics: By slugging Australians with a rate hike this Melbourne Cup Day, the RBA has shown it has backed the wrong horse. It's the rate rise the Australian economy didn't need. With a slowing economy, supply driven inflation, a more volatile geopolitical and global economic outlook, and past rate rises still to take full effect, mortgage holders and businesses seeking capital to invest will pay the price today. With increases to the cash rate only effective at reducing demand-led inflation, it is hard to see what a November rate hike achieves other than making it harder for Australians to pay their mortgage in the lead-up to Christmas. David Bassanese, chief economist at Betashares: The Federal Treasurer's public interventions to downplay the need for higher interest rates, moreover, likely only hardened the RBA's resolve — indeed, for the sake of being seen to be independent, it was even more important for the bank to raise interest rates today. The cruel irony of the current situation is that the more that households not affected by higher interest rates keep spending with abandon, the more RBA is forced to screw down on those that are affected. Only stronger fiscal policy would provide for a fairer burden of restraint but that seems very unlikely anytime soon. It also does not help that a lack of competitive pressure in some sectors — from groceries to travel — is likely keeping inflation stickier than would otherwise be the case. But again, measures to improve product market competition are nowhere to be seen. Brendan Rynne, chief economist at KPMG: In KPMG's view the RBA could have held for another month to assess the situation. There are enough market signals to suggest aggregate demand is continuing to decline. A softness is appearing in the labour market and is only likely to grow over the coming months; retail lending rates are rising due to increasing wholesale funding costs and the immediate impact associated with any cash rate rise is going to be disproportionately felt by the poorest in society — the cohort that are least adding to inflationary pressures in Australia. The economy is showing more signs that it is weakening because of past rate rises.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economists broadly expected today's rate hike, but the reaction has been mixed

children.content: Most economists had expected the RBA would lift rates by 0.25 percentage points at today's meeting — but the response to the decision has been varied.
Here's how some have reacted to the development.
Stephen Smith, Deloitte Access Economics:
By slugging Australians with a rate hike this Melbourne Cup Day, the RBA has shown it has backed the wrong horse.
It's the rate rise the Australian economy didn't need.

With a slowing economy, supply driven inflation, a more volatile geopolitical and global economic outlook, and past rate rises still to take full effect, mortgage holders and businesses seeking capital to invest will pay the price today.

With increases to the cash rate only effective at reducing demand-led inflation, it is hard to see what a November rate hike achieves other than making it harder for Australians to pay their mortgage in the lead-up to Christmas.
David Bassanese, chief economist at Betashares:

The Federal Treasurer's public interventions to downplay the need for higher interest rates, moreover, likely only hardened the RBA's resolve — indeed, for the sake of being seen to be independent, it was even more important for the bank to raise interest rates today.

The cruel irony of the current situation is that the more that households not affected by higher interest rates keep spending with abandon, the more RBA is forced to screw down on those that are affected. Only stronger fiscal policy would provide for a fairer burden of restraint but that seems very unlikely anytime soon.

It also does not help that a lack of competitive pressure in some sectors — from groceries to travel — is likely keeping inflation stickier than would otherwise be the case. But again, measures to improve product market competition are nowhere to be seen.
Brendan Rynne, chief economist at KPMG:
In KPMG's view the RBA could have held for another month to assess the situation.
There are enough market signals to suggest aggregate demand is continuing to decline.
A softness is appearing in the labour market and is only likely to grow over the coming months; retail lending rates are rising due to increasing wholesale funding costs
and the immediate impact associated with any cash rate rise is going to be disproportionately felt by the poorest in society —
the cohort that are least adding to inflationary pressures in Australia.
The economy is showing more signs that it is weakening because of past rate rises.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Three Palestinian human rights groups have launched legal action in the Federal Court of Australia seeking to gain access to records on arms exports to Israel, according to a statement from the Australian Centre for International Justice who is supporting the application. Al-Haq, Al Mezan Centre for Human Rights and the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights said they are seeking "access to all permits allowing the export of arms and weapons to Israel that have been granted by the Minister for Defence since 7 October". "Australia's role in exporting arms material to Israel must be exposed. If Australian-made weapons are being used against Palestinian civilians, our clients and the public deserve to know", Rawan Arraf, Executive Director at the Australian Centre for International Justice (ACIJ), and solicitor for the Palestinian human rights groups said. "Countries providing arms to enable Israel's brutal violence against the Palestinian people must be transparent. And Australia must not be complicit in that violence", she said. "We know that hundreds of permits have been issued in recent years, but the Australian government keeps the basic details secret: what items are being exported, who is making them, what are they used for?" It is the first legal challenge attempting to shed light on arms exports permits in Australia, ACIJ said. "We are seeing the makings of a genocide unfold in front of our eyes", Issam Younis, Director General Secretary at Al Mezan Centre for Human Rights, said. "If Australia is selling Israel the means to commit that genocide, it would not only be an unspeakable horror committed against the Palestinian people, it would breach Australia's obligations under international law and its own rules around arms exports." The ABC reached out to the Department of Defence for comment but has not received a response at the time of publication.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian human rights groups launch legal action to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel

"Australia's role in exporting arms material to Israel must be exposed. If Australian-made weapons are being used against Palestinian civilians, our clients and the public deserve to know",
Rawan Arraf, Executive Director at the Australian Centre for International Justice (ACIJ)
, and solicitor for the Palestinian human rights groups said.
"Countries providing arms to enable Israel's brutal violence against the Palestinian people must be transparent. And Australia must not be complicit in that violence", she said.

"We know that hundreds of permits have been issued in recent years, but the Australian government keeps the basic details secret: what items are being exported, who is making them, what are they used for?"
It is the first legal challenge attempting to shed light on arms exports permits in Australia, ACIJ said.
"We are seeing the makings of a genocide unfold in front of our eyes",
Issam Younis
, Director General Secretary at Al Mezan Centre for Human Rights, said.

"If Australia is selling Israel the means to commit that genocide, it would not only be an unspeakable horror committed against the Palestinian people, it would breach Australia's obligations under international law and its own rules around arms exports."
The ABC reached out to the Department of Defence for comment but has not received a response at the time of publication.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) has appealed to international health and relief organisations to "provide essential aid and supplies" to northern Gaza. The fuel reserves for Al Quds Hospital 's power generator are anticipated to run out within 48 hours, the organisation added in a statement posted on X. It said Israel's blockade on Gaza was posing "an eminent threat" to the operation of ambulances, emergency services, hospitals and the relief of displaced individuals by preventing essential resources from entering. "The hospital's fuel reserves will run out within 48 hours, and life-saving equipment, neonatal incubators, and intensive care units will cease to function", it said. "Additionally, there is a severe shortage of medical supplies, medicines and a significant lack of food and drinking water for medical staff, patients, and the wounded." It said more than 14,000 displaced people had been residing within the hospital's premises for more than three weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian Red Crescent Society appeals for urgent international aid for hospitals

children.content: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society
(PRCS) has appealed to international health and relief organisations to "provide essential aid and supplies" to northern Gaza.
The fuel reserves for
Al Quds Hospital
's power generator are anticipated to run out within 48 hours, the organisation added in a statement posted on X.

It said Israel's blockade on Gaza was posing "an eminent threat" to the operation of ambulances, emergency services, hospitals and the relief of displaced individuals by preventing essential resources from entering.
"The hospital's fuel reserves will run out within 48 hours, and life-saving equipment, neonatal incubators, and intensive care units will cease to function", it said.
"Additionally, there is a severe shortage of medical supplies, medicines and a significant lack of food and drinking water for medical staff, patients, and the wounded."
It said more than 14,000 displaced people had been residing within the hospital's premises for more than three weeks.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: About 100 pro-Palestinian protesters have been disrupting traffic at an Ascot Vale intersection as thousands of punters continue to make their way to Flemington Racecourse ahead of the running of the Cup, according to police. Police say the protesters arrived about 11am at the Epsom Road, Ascot Vale Road and Racecourse Road roundabout and caused traffic disruptions. Two protesters, including a woman who climbed onto the roof of a white van and refused to get down, were pepper-sprayed and arrested, according to police. Police say the incident remains ongoing, with about 80 protesters at the scene, and they have arranged for the van to be towed away.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pro-Palestinian protesters disrupt traffic near Melbourne Cup

children.content: About 100 pro-Palestinian protesters have been disrupting traffic at an Ascot Vale intersection as thousands of punters continue to make their way to Flemington Racecourse ahead of the running of the Cup, according to police.
Police say the protesters arrived about 11am at the Epsom Road, Ascot Vale Road and Racecourse Road roundabout and caused traffic disruptions.

props.alt: People wearning helmets and hats standing on top of a van with a ladder on it and cops around

(AAP: Con Chronis)

Police say the incident remains ongoing, with about 80 protesters at the scene, and they have arranged for the van to be towed away.
